thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Lifehack: buy T05 first, then once it wears out, buy T80, or vice versa.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: This way you will learn by yourself how these rubbers play for you.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: And the difference between them is not that big so you can go from one to another with a minimal adjustment.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Depend on your skill.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: I like hard sponge so t05 is my favorite.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: The sponge on T05, T80, T64 and T25 is all the same.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: The difference is not the sponge.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: It is the pimple construction.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: T64 has longer thinner pimples with more space between pimples so the pips give more and the rubber feels softer.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: T05 pimples are a little shorter, thicker, and closer together so the rubber feels harder.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: But even the rubber in the topsheet is the same.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Just the pimple construction is different.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: I won't comment on T25; but T05, T80 and T64 are all great rubbers.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: There are people whose game and style of play may work with one of them slightly better than the others.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: But they are all really great rubbers.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: To sum the info up simply:

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: 1) T05: Slower, More Spin, Higher Throw Angle.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: 2) T64: Faster, Less Spin, Lower Throw Angle.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: So do you want a bigger arc, more spin to spin the person off the table but a little sacrifice in speed?

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Or do you want lower shots that don't come up as much and are faster.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: But with an amount of spin that is easier to counter.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Or do you want to be half way in between the two extremes?

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: I go with slower and more spin every time.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Especially since T05 is more than fast enough.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Tenergy has a slightly higher throw angle than Baracuda, so looping heavy chops may be a little bit easier, with a greater arc on the ball.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: However, Baracuda still has a medium-high throw so they're both perfectly fine for looping.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: In my personal opinion, Baracuda has more spin than Tenergy, however it lacks a little bit of power and control compared to Ten.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Tenergy often has many complaints of it being incredibly heavy per sheet, but many reviews say it is worth it.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Ultimately, with a heavier top-sheet comes more power, but you can adjust this with your sponge layer.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Baracuda is not as heavy, but in my opinion, just as good.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Tenergy 05 reacts quite a bit to topspin, although if you have an ALL blade, it should be fine.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Baracuda is very good with incoming spin, and would be fine with any blade.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Just remember to keep your bat angle low.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Tenergy has many complaints of it being non-durable.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Some reviewers claim that with only a few days of playing with it, obvious cracks were in the rubber on the side.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Just don't throw it around on the table.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Maybe because the topsheet is a little bit harder.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: I can't really comment how easy either one is to use, since they're suited for different playing styles.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Tenergy is noticeably faster than Baracuda, though not quite as spinny.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: If driving's your thing, use Tenergy.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: If long, spinny rallies is how you tend to lean towards, Baracuda would be a better rubber.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: In conclusion,

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Ten has higher throw angle

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Ten is heavier

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Ten is more sensitive to incoming topspin, though can be adjusted with blade or sponge layer

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Bara is much more durable (according to reviewers)

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: I also personally think that Baracuda is a much better rubber in terms of worth for money.

thread_title: Fastarc G-1 (vs. Baracuda)
reply_split: Unlike the others that started with a bang and then sank into oblivion, Fastarc G-1 has been in and out the top 10 of Table Tennis Kingdom sales ranking during the last years of 40mm, and only really became a best-seller well after the switch to the 40+(July, 2014).

thread_title: Fastarc G-1 (vs. Baracuda)

thread_title: Rakza 7 vs Evolution MX-S?

thread_title: Rakza 7 vs Evolution MX-S?
reply_split: I can play very slow spinny loops during warmup without much effort - that is how grippy G1 topsheet is and how easy it is to spin with it.

thread_title: Rakza 7 vs Evolution MX-S?

thread_title: Rakza 7 vs Evolution MX-S?

thread_title: Rakza 7 vs Evolution MX-S?

thread_title: DHS vs. Tensor - long term investment
reply_split: The thing with tacky Chinese rubbers in the backhand is that when it comes to a bh to bh rally or punchblocking, the ball has a tendency to hit the net.

thread_title: DHS vs. Tensor - long term investment
reply_split: This can be resolved by slightly brushing the ball but it is easier to just use a german or jap rubber.

thread_title: DHS vs. Tensor - long term investment
reply_split: If you like hurricane 3 then get an alternative hard rubber in the backhand that is spinny but also gives you bounce.

thread_title: DHS vs. Tensor - long term investment
reply_split: Mantra h 2.0mm, joola maxxx 500 2.0mm, xiom vega tour and many other rubbers.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Jap style rubbers, for example Palio AK47 red or blue, would spin your ball not less than tacky STN, but these are just "grippy" top sheets and not sticky at all.Sure you know it better than me that tackiness in Chinese classic rubbers is to compensate for the otherwise short dwell time because of hard sponge.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Did you notice that if top sheet is not tacky then it will not have hard sponge.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: And opposite, if there is hard sponge then topsheet is made tacky to win back some dwell time.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: So what I am trying to say here that when we choose to go for tacky Chinese rubbers we normally want to get that hard sponge on the racket, tackiness comes as extra little bonus.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Our playing style then different - full body rotation, power from your hips and etc (ask boxer does he hit using hand power or hips and torso power?

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: You might be very surprised ...) Similar mechanics here.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power

reply_split: There's the Japanese scale, there's the ESN scale, there's the 729 scale, there's the DHS scale... 42 on the 729 scale would be a medium hard rubber, all those "training sheets" from various manufacturers are usually 42 on the 729 scale.

thread_title: Backhand rubber - Sanwei T-88 Taiji/Palio Aeolus/neither?
reply_split: I mean, I can TELL the difference if I stop to think, but it doesn't effect my game, since I find the differences subtle, even if it's six month old Rakza X and a brand new sheet of $5 Palio Generic Dragon.

thread_title: Backhand rubber - Sanwei T-88 Taiji/Palio Aeolus/neither?

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: Hi, I have used the Focus III extensively 5 years ago and recently bought the AK47 Blue.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: For a direct comparison the AK47 Blue is slightly faster but actually significantly less grip so you are not going to get higher throw from it.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: It is also a little bit heavier (but still in the light rubbers category so not too much of a concern).

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: For a cheapy with higher surface grip, try the ktl series (pro XP, Rapid Sound etc) both are almost as light and a bit more spinny, speed as with the Focus on the medium-low side.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: I always felt F+S III was a very soft rubber but Palio AK-47 blue is a lot harder and heavier sponge.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: FSIII is better and easier at flat kills and brush loops.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: AK-47 blue is more loop kill and loop drive and needs a very pronounced stroke and not very forgiving.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: I am unable to compare "throw" for either as I tried these rubbers on different blades and felt it was close enough to feel the same.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: AK-47 comes in red,yellow and blue branding and I don't know about the other 2 since have not tried them.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: Thank you man iii and lasta for your replies.I actually went and bought a pair of Gewo Hype EL 40 rubbers in 1.9 sponge about 3 months ago.Have to say I've been very impressed with them so far.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: My game has improved noticeably.They are a tiny bit heavier than the Snipe III but I got used to the weight difference very quickly.They play similar to the Snipe but offer a little more control / placement and a lot more spin.The throw is also slightly higher than the Snipe and the arc is greater too.In fact I would say that they do everything that the Snipe did but just that little bit better in all aspects.Speed, control, spin are all noticeably better with the Hype El 40.Is the Hype EL worth the extra cost compared to the Snipe?All things considered I would say yes.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Without knowing enough about your level or how long you have been playing or what your playing style is it is hard to give good advice but I will try.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: If you like to step away from the table and play loops and topspin drives then the Tenergy is a great rubber for that.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: The blade is also a factor.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: A good looping blade such as the Nittaku Violin will also be high throw so you need to adjust accordingly.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Maybe you need to stand a bit further back than you already are?

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Maybe your technique is the issue?

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Faster hand speed will always help the ball curve down more and land on the table.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: More brushing, less hitting through the ball.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: I am just assuming a lot of things about your game here.If you plan to play a close-to-the-table kind of game, are you saying you want to play a more push block sort of game?

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: In that case I don't think the Tenergy is the right rubber since it is springy and high throw.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: You will need a stiffer racket or a harder sponge, or both for that type of game to work.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: T05 is fine for close to the table controlled spin play.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: You will need more compact strokes to adjust to the shorter recovery time, that's all.And it's a good general rule to change one thing at a time.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: So change your preferred distance now, keep the same equipment.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: When you settle in at the new distance, if you still want to change equipment then do it.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: That way you will get a clear evaluation of each change.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Thanks for the advance.I played County as a kid and had a low national ranking.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: (mid 90s) then had a 10 year break played in local league for a season and won promotion from middle division of 5 to 2nd top (top division contained players from strong British league teams).

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Currently back in local league... Making too many mistakes and wanting to push on and get promoted up the divisions.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Using Primorac off- blade

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: The main drawback of Tenergy 05 is that it's quite sensitive to incoming spin from your opponent.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: So if that's the cause of many mistakes, and it outweighs the number of winners you hit, only then it'w worth considering something else.Are you using 2.1mm or 1.9mm?

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: The blade is certainly good for looping, with tons of control.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: I always preferred 64 over 05 for short action/close to the table counterlooping.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: But I don't think it was intended for that...

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Short pips?

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: Is one of them significantly harder then the others?

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: You probably have the purple/lavender/mauve or whatever you'd like to call it, which is 36-38° as it is used with the 2-side-loop version and on the softer biotech CJ8000.You can crank the hardness up up to 42-44° by just buying the related version but I recommend to try no harder than 40-42° first.

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: And you also could obtain a CJ8000 topsheet and combine it with any other sponge you may like.

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: Yours should be the B-type topsheet but the C-type, as it is used on the Light&Fast-version, may suit you as well.There's also a tensor-version and versions with japanese sponges but they may feel even softer than your 36-38° sponge.

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: Found the CJ8000 Speed with 43 deg sponge.

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: Sounds really good to me:-)

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: What I would suggest is - buy two different ones.

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: Get the hardest one, and the softest one.

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: Mount them both on the same blade, see if 1) you can actually tell the difference, and 2) if it MAKES any difference.

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: You probably WILL be able to TELL the difference, but it won't MAKE any difference unless you're a very high level player.

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: You'll probably PREFER one over the other just by the way they feel, though.

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: Then get another two from in between, and repeat!

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: If you're messing with CJ8000, you'll probably find yourself dealing with the "dish" problem.

thread_title: Neo Skyline 2 or Giant Dragon Storm for beginner/returner??
reply_split: Be patient getting the rubber onto the blade.

thread_title: 5Q sound or Andro rasant beat
reply_split: Whats your take on tacky rubbers on fh?

thread_title: 5Q sound or Andro rasant beat
reply_split: fast rubbers like t-05 and mxp kinda hinders progression of individual technique and too reliant on the rubbers itself providing you energy vs you swinging properly to make a good play.

thread_title: 5Q sound or Andro rasant beat
reply_split: E.g a small flick of wrist would propels the ball in a forgiving manner on t-05 vs say hurricane 3.

thread_title: 5Q sound or Andro rasant beat
reply_split: If u hate tacky rubbers, I'd recommend the usual thing I'd recommend my friends, rakza 7, xiom vega pro ( I myself am getting vega asia soon) , personally haven't tried andro, and the thibar I've tried like MXP is top notch but maybe a tad too fast for my level on my blades right now.The relation to high throw and high control differs from individual, but to me if i were to give comparison of it, t05 vs mxp, on loops with big arm swings t05 goes higher and easier to consistently hit the opponent's side of table, while mxp has a lower and acute angle and travels further needs quite a good precision when using it, bear in mind both rubbers ive tried were on diff blades and both all wood.

thread_title: 5Q sound or Andro rasant beat
reply_split: All in all , don't delve too much on what rubbers you use, each have small intricacies that cater to different players, and small quirks that some players like some doesn't, but with good training, given time you can eliminate all the factors ( throw angle, speed etc) of the rubbers and make it work for your game.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: For someone who has had little or no coaching you seem to be putting the effort into looking at how to improve.If you're dissatisfied with your FH rubber (I've no experience of jpen) you could consider sticking with the same rubber in a not so soft version - the Vega Europe.The Baracuda I wouldn't recommend - it's essentially an old rubber but for the Spin & Speed it gives it's not great on control.Genius Sound I know nothing about but it's rated at 37.5 degree compared to the 42.5 degree of the Baracuda.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Am I wrong in thinking that a higher throw angle results in a greater arc+spin, thus causing the ball to land sooner (And in turn further in from the edge of the table)?Thank you so much for your input!

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: I did a little search on your blade and it comes up as stiff and fast.A high throw rubber compensates for the stiffness giving a better arc allowing one to land balls on the table more easily.Problem with high throw rubbers is control.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Most opt for medium throw on the BH for control reserving the high throw for the FH.If you're starting off it's not recommended to have a stiff blade and a high throw rubber.The little that I know of pips is that a stiff blade is beneficial.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Personally I would compromise the stiffness for more flexibility allowing you to use medium to low throw rubbers so that you can get your technique right and learn to play more easily with looping etc.So maybe another thread might be needed to see if you could use a less stiff jpen blade ?Normally with a rubber the arc starts to flatten out the harder you hit - only exception that I've found is the Tenergy 05 which I would not recommend for you given the control issues with it.So if you have a slightly harder sponge it tends to keep its arc and in practice is more consistent than a soft sponge.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: So depending how you hit the Vega Europe may prove better to play with than the Vega Elite despite having the same throw rating.If you plan on sticking with your current stiff fast jpen blade I would be inclined to use a non tensor technology rubber for better control to allow better development.I've recommended the Stiga Magna TC II before.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Technically rated as a tensor and it seems it can be used / or was designed with speed glue in mind.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Using normal glue it should be fine.

thread_title: Which Euro/Jap rubber beats Tenergy for pushing/serving?
reply_split: As I get to return serves all the time from all the top players at our association, the spinniest serves and pushes would come from our Chinese ex-provincial members who use DHS H3 or Haifu Whale... Definitely heavier in spin than T05, perhaps by about 25%... Other non-Chinese rubbers that can produce roughly the same amount of spin as T05 in serves and pushes are Calibra LT, Acuda S1, Stiga Boost TP and Yasaka Rakza 7... Maybe T05 could push heavier than these, but I do not feel it from Zaman M. or Justin N... As a matter of fact I have never felt T05 users could overpower me with extra spin than most other non-Chinese inverted...

thread_title: Which Euro/Jap rubber beats Tenergy for pushing/serving?
reply_split: This is my completely impartial view, despite the fact that I've spoken out against Butterfly's pricing numerous times... Now if T05 users feel they can produce spin easier (and with better control) than its competitors, that could very well be true, but there's definitely a ceiling on this rubber's spin capability that I feel is not superior to many rubbers out there.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: The bottom line is that M2 is the first " T05 alternative" I have tried that is acceptable, this after 4+ years with T05 and after spending way too much money on alternatives that I ripped off my blade in disgust, sometimes after just five minutes of play (see below).

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: M2 doesn't feel exactly like T05.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: It is a touch slower, and the ball feels different.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: Not worse, just different.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: It is an excellent feel, though.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: Some people have described it as more "liquid" and that is about right, as if the top sheet is more pliant.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: The thing is, if you are used to T05, you can play exactly the same way, and play just as well without having to make many adjustments at all.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: You can get the same high arc spins, you can use pretty much the same racket angles.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: I have not found that to be the case with any of the "alternatives" that have been touted over the last several years.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: If I had to cite differences, I would be that M2 does not feel quite as nice as T05 on blocks (although I certainly made the shot just as well), and it really shines on opening loops against underspin, or counterloops.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: It could be that M1 would be better in that regard, I haven't tried it yet.It has a very strong smell -- exactly the same smell as the Dandoy Bio Boost and the Tibhar booster -- and there is no doubt that it comes heavily factory-tuned.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: Some people have said that they actually like it better after some of that tuning wears off.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: I will report later how that goes.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: But if performance declines, well I will know how to bring it back.Rasant is not one of the alternatives I've tried, so I can't compare.

thread_title: Thin fast rubber or thicker slower rubber

thread_title: Bty Tackiness C or Tibhar Super Def 40
reply_split: I use TIbhar Super Defense 40 Soft on a Xiom Aigis blade, and have wondered how the spin on the Tibhar rubber compares to that from Tackiness C. From various ratings, such as from Paddle Palace and others, it does seem as that the spin rating for TIbhar Super Defense 40 is markedly greater than that for Tackiness C. However, from this forum, and others, I get the impression that most people are very pleased with the amount of spin with Tackiness C.

thread_title: Bty Tackiness C or Tibhar Super Def 40
reply_split: it`s been a while but:heavier backspin with tackiness c ball lands shorter on table with tackiness c loop is better/lower with super def 40 more spin on serve with tackiness c more control with tackiness c  the surface is grippy for super def,mild tack for tackiness c the catapult is higher for super def.....both rubbers were tested on def alpha and donic defplay,i prefered them on the donic although the most underspin was tackiness c 1.1 on def alpha,if the ball went long there was enough underspin to bring it back under the table almost to me(non grippy floor)

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: M2 is only tacky for few weeks then it will become very grippy, like a very spinny euro rubber.H3 has thicker and harder topsheet and will stay tacky throughout it's life.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: mercury II (37°) is a bit springy, higher and slower than H3 but equal (almost) on spin, but it does bottom out in a harder stroke.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: sponge is really fragile, better not reglue.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: i recommend using on a hard/carbon blade.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: topsheet in h3 is a lot harder and therefore less forgiving (if you don't brush thinly enough or with enough decision you will miss).also the sponge in h3 is harder.mercury 2 37 RED is much harder than 37 BLACK and less brittle.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: black will bubble after 3 days, red never does.speedwise, mercury2 37 red is faster than NEO H3 on stiff blades, slower on flexible blades.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: in general, DHS rubbers are very slow on stiff blades, I am not sure why.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: maybe out of the packet.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: but once worn in they are quite fast on stiff blades like clipper

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: I've used a couple 37 blacks, no durability issues for me.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: Maybe you got a bad batch or something?

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: DHS rubbers on stiff blades are very difficult to use, the dwell time is too small, so you tend to brush more than usual to control it resulting in the slower apparent speed.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: That's my hypothesis anyway!

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: The Mercury II is definitely bouncier, and when new it's tackier too.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: However, both rubbers lose their tack pretty quickly, the H3Neo loses it in a week and the Mercury II in about 2 months.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: Doesn't really matter though as long as you use adhesive rubber covers as they'll restore the tack.The bottom line is that the H3Neo plays like a traditional Chinese rubber, while the Mercury II plays like an Eurojap rubber with a lot of tack.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: In other words, other than the tackiness, and I suppose a similar throw, the two really have nothing in common.Note that I've used 3 sheets of retail H3Neo, 1 commercial(ttnpp) at roughly 41 degrees, 1 provincial 40 degrees(ttnpp), 1 provincial 39 degrees(prott.cc), all black at 2.15mm.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: The 40 degree one and the commercial one played almost exactly alike, other than of course one being a bit softer.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: This is despite the commercial one measuring at 51 grams while the 40 degree provincial one was only 43 grams.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: The 39 degree one, however, was a completely different animal.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: First, it came out of the package with a TREMENDOUS reverse dome.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: The rubber would literally roll up on itself, with ends overlapping, while the other two would lie almost flat.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: It was a real pain in the neck to glue and especially reglue, BTW.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: Its weight was in between, at about 48 grams.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: Perhaps due to the reverse dome and the softer sponge, it feels to have much better dwell and spin than the other two, while being a bit slower.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: The differences are pretty noticeable, which is a bit surprising since the difference between the other two were barely detectable.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: The moral of the story I suppose is that different batches of H3Neo could play differently, even between provincial versions!

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: H3 neo looses tack in a week.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: I did mention that it goes away in about a week, it's in the first paragraph.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: However, using adhesive rubber covers restores the tack.

thread_title: h3 neo or mercury II forehand rubber?
reply_split: I only clean my rubbers with water and cloth.

reply_split: They are totally different rubbers, Mercury II plays very similar to an ESN tensor except is has less spin potential, most players can't make the potential of the ESN rubbers anyway so that's ok.H3 only has half that bounce and plays almost like a old time traditional Chinese tacky

thread_title: Are Tenergies or other Butterfly rubbers vacuum packed?

thread_title: Are Tenergies or other Butterfly rubbers vacuum packed?

thread_title: Are Tenergies or other Butterfly rubbers vacuum packed?
reply_split: Dan2105 is right.

thread_title: Are Tenergies or other Butterfly rubbers vacuum packed?
reply_split: The holes are also standard for the packaging.

thread_title: Are Tenergies or other Butterfly rubbers vacuum packed?
reply_split: Okay.How long can it sit for?Thanks!

thread_title: Are Tenergies or other Butterfly rubbers vacuum packed?
reply_split: I would guess that in a cool place, at least a year, probably several years.

thread_title: Are Tenergies or other Butterfly rubbers vacuum packed?
reply_split: If they are indeed tuned (I think they are) there may be some slight drop-off in performance, but it's not likely to happen for months.

thread_title: Are Tenergies or other Butterfly rubbers vacuum packed?
reply_split: Remember they sit on the manufacturer and them the distributor/retailer shelves for some time before they're sold already, so they can't afford to make them to go off too quickly.

thread_title: Are Tenergies or other Butterfly rubbers vacuum packed?
reply_split: As haggisv said, as long as you store them in a cool dry place and sealed in their packaging, there is no reason why you couldn't wait a few weeks to use them.

thread_title: Donic Traction MS Pro/Soft rubbers

thread_title: Donic Traction MS Pro/Soft rubbers

thread_title: Donic Traction MS Pro/Soft rubbers
reply_split: Calibra's throw was a little higher, but both lifted backspin effortlessly and counterloop very nicely.

thread_title: Donic Traction MS Pro/Soft rubbers

thread_title: Donic Traction MS Pro/Soft rubbers
reply_split: In the short game the Donic clearly outperformed, as the Calibra is much more bouncy making it harder to keep the ball low.Serving was very good with both...both generate heavy spin easily, although with the Donic it's a little easier to serve slower balls and probably a little easier to generate the spin.If I had to chose, I'd personally choose the Calibra, but that depends on your own game.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: Stop stressing about equipment, yours is fine.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: The feel of a setup is a very personal choice, decided by both the player's playing style and pure personal preference.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: A "mushy" blade can be very good at looping and the short game, but they're generally not good for blocking and hitting.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: If Robot Blocker, as his name suggests, is a blocker, then it would be natural for him to prefer a harder blade as they do block more precisely.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: A soft and flexible setup has very good control and spin for loops, but as you step up in level and need more speed, then your shots will need to have more hitting components to them(e.g.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: loop drives, counter hits, etc.).

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: THEN, harder setups will be more useful.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: Unless you become a hitter/blocker, then hard and flexy setups will be the way to go once you reach that level.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: re blade vs rubber combos.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: for anyone still learning and discovering what kind of player they will be it's best to use a not very flexible soft allround 5 ply (mushy blade).

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: Once you get enough skill to engage in long distance rallys you will want to or need to move to a thin flexible blade, if you decide you will play offensively near the table you might be better with a hard feel 7 ply like a clipper with softer rubbers.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: The thicker 7 plys don't need heavy rubbers since they don't rely so much on flex, the harder thin and flexible 5 plys do need heavier rubber to induce the flex which lets them play so far from the table.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: I bet the XT and XP would play great on a Clipper but it'll be too fast for a intermediate player unless they are offensive on every shot.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: There are plenty of blades somewhere in the middle of all this but that's the basics.The type of blade that seem to have no point in life are the soft 7 plys like Joola Viva or something like that

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: Mid distance looping is the only thing I am good at (well for my level anyway), the combination overall only cost about 30$, so it wont hurt to try!

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: If it does not work, I can merely replace the rubbers

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: Of course it won't.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: Every time you try something, you learn something.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: That's not to say you always learn something good.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: And its not to say you will become better, the more you try.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: What is important is getting something that reasonably suits you and practice with it.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: Do I recall you saying you get about 2 hours of practice every day?

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: You will grow in the game at a good rate if you keep this up.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: Who do you practice against, that is part of the key!

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: There is a huge range of people at the club that I play against, I have approximately 30 minute rotations between each person.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: I feel it helps me get a range of different styles that I have learnt to play against.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: Do you suggest for me to designate a single person?

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: No, a range of people is good.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: Although the better your opponent, the better you will be forced to be yourself.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: This is a good point, variety is great, but also try to play against better opponents at any opportunity.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: A couple months ago I was at practice and the only other player not already playing was a beginner and I offered to have a hit with him, he wanted to decline, saying I was too good for him and that he would swap around with someone else.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: I insisted that it would be a good warm up as we both just got there, and got him out on the court.

thread_title: LKT Pro Xt or XP?
reply_split: The following week he actually commented to me saying he played much better in a couple of practice matches that night after warming up with me, found his stroke was a bit more consistent and handled his opponents faster shots a bit better.

thread_title: LKT pro Xp/Xt/red diamond
reply_split: had a good hit around with the Red Diamond on a Galaxy W6 blade.i take it the rubber needs a good break in unlike the xp/xt rubbers, as a simple bounce test showed that the ball clinged onto the rubber and died out very fast like it would with H3.so far counter hitting and blocking was very precise and easy with RD, rubber altogether felt quite hard, H3 hard if not harder, quite close to H2 then again if not more.. it felt quite tacky/sticky( fresh h3 or 729-05 have that feeling)but it didnt react to oncoming spin like H3 would the ball seemed to stay a lot lower kinda like H2 but not as viciousalso its quite heavy heavier than H3.it generated good spin, but it didnt come as naturally as it would have with xp/xt..will have to see what its like after it gets broken in proper, if it requires it that is.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: I just started using H2 Neo after having used Tenergy 25 for 4-5 months and seeing a nice rating boost.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: H2 Neo is upping my rating again, due mainly to its greater consistency: My coaches and opponents tell me I'm simply getting more balls on the table.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: And H2 is clearly harder for opponents to deal with; a quality that's not often talked about when inverted rubber is being discussed (it has to do with H2's ball path and kick off the table, as well as its spin variations).H2 Neo's spin on serve is on par with T25, possibly even stronger.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: H2 Neo starts out tacky but it mostly wears off after 5-6 matches and the speed increases as the tackiness decreases.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: Another FH rubber to consider is DHS Skyline TG3 Neo which I'm currently testing.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: Faster and harder than H2 Neo, TG3 Neo is even tackier and seems to have somewhat higher throw, and noticeably more spin on serve.My experience with Palio Thors is mixed.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: I test hit with a brand new sheet some months back and absolutely hated it, as did several other 1800+ players who tried it that day.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: It was very tacky and non-linear, where hard strokes were rockets, but any stroke with less power could unexpectedly land in the net.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: Otoh, I tried another player's well broken in Thors -- so much so that it had a dull spot in the hitting zone -- and was astounded at how different it was than the brand new sheet I had tried previously.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: The broken in Thors was, hands down, the best blocking rubber I had ever used: Effortless high-speed blocks off of blistering incoming drives had me instantly grinning.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: Linearity was fine, and speed and spin were great.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: But whether I want to endure a break-in period that may be dozens of matches long is something I haven't committed to.. yet.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: You can play well with H2 neo or Thors but they are fairly different rubbers and like nathanso said regarding Thors changing with age the difference between them grows with age, the H2 neo will get slower, Thors will get faster.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: A brand new Thors is still faster than H2 neo will ever be and more spinny but once it's got 30, 40 maybe 50 hours on it, then it's quite fast and also very lively.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: I've got a sheet with around 200 hours on it and I still like it more than a new sheet.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: The thing about H2 is that is one of the least side spin reactive rubbers you can get and Thors is possibly the most sidespin reactive rubber you can get, they both make similar topspin but Thors does it more easily and also will curve the ball on sidespin a lot further than H2 can.H2 neo is much easier to control, and again like nathanso said H2 is very difficult for opponents to read the spin and be able to return the ball, because it flys flat with heavy spin it's a very unusual rubber and something almost no one is used to.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: I'm not 100% happy with either H2 or Thors as a complete package and both have flaws which you have to play around.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: In the end I can use either H2 or Thors and play at the same level whatever but Thors is a much more powerful rubber and because you can bend the ball around the net at will and win points from full court length + do all kinds of trick stuff so easily it's much more fun to use so I'll choose it over H2 just for the fun factor since it doesn't cost me points although anywhere much below 2000 us level I think you would be better served with H2 just because it's so much easier to control.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: Make no mistake Thors is harder to use at full pace than any other tensor and any tenergy, it's very demanding but that seems the price you have to pay for a very powerful tacky rubber.The third rubber nathanso mentioned TG3 is probably the best bet for most people since it more side spinny than H2, not quite as deceptive as H2 but is more easy to use than either Thors or H2, it's actually softer in the top sheet than H2 and has the same sponge so any feeling of it being harder is just go old DHS variation or a harder degree sponge.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: The tackiness varies wildly also, some TG3 are very tacky and some aren't hardly tacky at all, just depends on what day it was made, all the red DHS rubbers are more consistant in this way and I only buy red sheets of DHS rubbers now because of that reason, they tend to be "just right", they also last longer The end of the story I think is for you who naturally hits with sidespin.. Buy TG3 neo

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: Thanks for all the input there, especially about the TG3 Neo, I hadn't really considered it.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: It sounds like a happy median.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: I do use a lot of sidespin in my game, being left handed I play into people's crossover point with it.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: I also like the price of the neo's over Thors.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: As a reward for another 13 hour work day, I think I'll go ahead and buy me some.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: My experience with Thor, is that it does bottom out and there is no huge power gain from neo.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: I dont like it too much.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: I don't think that can be a bottoming out feeling... the sponge is simply too hard to bottom out IMO.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: The only time you can ever slightly bottom Thors is counter hitting a very well hit ball as hard as you can, I doubt more than 1% of the table tennis population can achieve that kind of speed, it happens a long time after T05 or any of the other famous tensors, when it does happen you can see the ball fly straighter than usual, normally it ends in a long ball even from full court.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: Imho the people that say it bottoms out easily are feeling the rubber and sponge going squirrly because it doesn't bottom out, when you get a rubber and blade combination just right for your power you want it to just kiss the blade on your biggest and best attacking shots, this gives the whole combo a nice stabilising effect and that's what you should always aim for.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: 2.1mm T05 will do that just nicely on the FH of a strong looper and I think it's one of the major reasons it's so popular with good players.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: Thors not being able to do that for anyone near mortal is it's only downfall as far as I can tell.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: It needs to be a bit softer or less tension in the sponge .

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: You can still use it just fine as it is as since you only bottom out the really top rubbers on big loops or counter hitting anyway, but it would be just that much better if it was more stable on those mission critical high pressure shots

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: I used Thors for 6 months plus and liked it, but now I have a coach and he has changed my playing style from driving hard/fast loops to a controlled spinning game on my FH.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: I had to go away from THors because it was very inconsistent with that pattern.

thread_title: H2 Neo or Thors?
reply_split: That said, my source of hard sponged kokataku has dried up and I am having bubble problems so I am in search of a new FH rubber.

thread_title: LKT Rapid Soft/Sound 1.8/2.0 on a fast balsa blade?
reply_split: Because the balsa rebounds the ball much faster when you hit it harder, the dwell time will be lower on powerloops so you'll likely get less spin.

thread_title: LKT Rapid Soft/Sound 1.8/2.0 on a fast balsa blade?
reply_split: So yes you can loop, but it will be more suitable for hitting and blocking.

thread_title: LKT Rapid Soft/Sound 1.8/2.0 on a fast balsa blade?
reply_split: You should be able to do slow spinny loops though, as this relies mostly on the rubber.

thread_title: Anyone use or try Donic Coppa Jo Silver?
reply_split: I'm currently using the Donic Coppa Jo Silver with a Kong Linghui Special Blade.Usually I play with a Xu Shaofa 999 and a Bryce Speed... so this is softer option for me.The Donic Coppa is very nice to play and give strong feedback in the hand.

thread_title: Anyone use or try Donic Coppa Jo Silver?
reply_split: The arylate carbon blade is a very good combination.The power is present mostly on mid-distance and the rubber is very soft and better for looping play vs hitting stroke.The throw is medium and the overall feeling is European.

thread_title: Anyone use or try Donic Coppa Jo Silver?
reply_split: My serve are less spinny, but I need less physical involvement to give dead shot.

thread_title: Anyone use or try Donic Coppa Jo Silver?
reply_split: It's more easy for me on FH cause the rubber is more insensitive to the opponent spin.The curve on my FH is less disturbing compare with the 999 but the speed is higher with a lovely nice sound.

thread_title: Anyone use or try Donic Coppa Jo Silver?

thread_title: Anyone use or try Donic Coppa Jo Silver?

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT
reply_split: People would just play into my backhand, unafraid of their own power being returned to them.

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT
reply_split: Actually I'm of the opinion that most bhs are a driving action with more solid contact than what a sticky rubber really requires.

thread_title: why not tacky on BH/ DHS TNT
reply_split: So most use a bh rubber that suits this action, which are non-sticky rubbers (ie, better normal force perpendicular to the rubber, whereas most sticky rubbers have better tangential)

thread_title: Review: JUIC Air Condle Sound / Speed
reply_split: A blade with a real low throw might be required to compensate for the appearant very high throw on fast loops.... or else I simply could not adjust my strokes to this rubber...The topsheets feels really grippy (almost tacky) but a little firm.

thread_title: Review: JUIC Air Condle Sound / Speed

thread_title: which rubber? T25 or bryce speed?

thread_title: which rubber? T25 or bryce speed?

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Very flat throw, with a low spin level make it the opposite of Tenergy.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Great for hitting at the table, excellent for pushing (seems to grip well on slow shots), consistent smashes.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: The downside is the low spin, which makes it hard work for loopers, but for blockers (you have to be good to control it though) and hitters it's excellent.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Pretty hard sponge lacks feel (on an Andro Super Core Off+) but gives a positive air to the rubber - it's getting the ball back rather than sinking in.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: If you're comparing it to Bryce Speed FX then Express 2 is the similar rubber (softer sponge), which will add some spin and feel at the expense of pace.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: I'm probably changing to Bryce Speed in the close season (May) unless the new toys they bring out look more fun.Also worth considering Andro Hexer - a loss of speed to the 2 above, but very accurate and quite spinny (can lift pushes easily) and plentry of gears.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Finally my review is here sorry for the delay but my initial excitment waned.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: As a new season is about to start, I decided to change my old Tenergy 05 both sides which I had been using to coach my students to a softer and faster BH rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I am a two wing looper who loves massive spin and speed produced from physical power and a grippy but not tacky top sheet.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: As many would agree there are few faults with Tenergy but as I use an all wood 4-ply blade I was wanting a softer sponge to allow more feeling on my BH loop.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: This is very important when having fun while playing against people like Haggisv who with his evil pimples I need all the feeling I can get LOL.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I have tried many of the latest glue effect rubbers from different companies and always felt none came close to the feeling of how I use to play with a glued up rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Then Haggisv lent me a new carbon blade and rubber from this French company whom I have never heard of and I really didn't like their rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It was all speed, little spin or control, but on the BH side was Haifu's Shark 2 tuned and I really liked it!

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It was so light and soft but had amazing power with a grippy Japanese type top sheet.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I went online shopping and came across Shark 3 and thought hmmm why not go for the top of the line it must be better than 2 because it had a 3 on the packaging LOL.Ok, enough background, lets get to the review.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Physical properties:Shark 3 is written on the package but on the rubber is Shark Speed, strange to have 2 names for one rubber but it comes in a vacuum packaging the same as Haifu's other tuned rubber like Blue Whale 2 and Shark 2.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I really was not expecting Shark 3 to be so DIFFERENT from Shark 2.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: When I tested the Shark 2 from Haggisv it used a light super soft yellow sponge but on Shark 3 it has a heavy dense pink sponge.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I included the pictures of the weights of my uncut Tenergy to compare the uncut Shark 3.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: There is a layer of glue on the back of the pink sponge but it is a lot thinner than the thick layer on my old Blue Whale 2.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Some people remove this layer to save weight but I think this layer adds to the bounce and feel of the rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The rubber has quite a good dome straight from the package, while the sponge being an unusual dark pink colour is quite dense and heavy, but is actually quite soft, nothing like any other Chinese rubber I have used.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Haifu mark this sponge as 34 degrees with their laser type etching on the bottom.This is the first rubber I have ever bought or heard of that has the degrees and thickness hand written on the sponge!

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The factory workers in China must have hand cramps if they mark every sponge personally.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The sponge has a strong chemical smell but in a nice way, almost fruity.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The top sheet is where this rubber stands out for me.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It is so beautiful to look at almost translucent with the Chinese characters looking amazing.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: This sheet is similar to a Japanese Bryce in its looks but feels very Chinese in its texture.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It is not tacky at all and can not pick up a ball from the table.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The sheet is extremely grippy just like Tenergy but in a more synthetic way.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Speed :For the grip this rubber has it has amazing speed Compared to my Tenergy on the same stroke and power it is about 20% faster.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I would not class it as a speed demon but 20% faster than Tenergy is still quite fast.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: For this amount of speed you get massive spin as well, unlike other speed only rubbers.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It is more springy than Tenergy but in a wonderful glue feel way.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I can feel the ball bite into the rubber and it feels like it stays there for a split moment then catapults out like my old speed glue rubbers.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: This feeling I have found missing in all my other glue effect rubbers, so I am thrilled that this Shark3 has this feeling as well as a HUGE click sound.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It is louder than any rubber I have tried without speed glue and even louder than my Donic F3 Big Slam which only gets its super loud click from a ridiculously super soft sponge.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Unlike the Big Slam and other soft sponge rubbers which bottom out so easily this Shark3 keeps on spinning and keeping control even with very strong power loops.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: However it does have its limits for a soft sponge so I agree with the recommendation from Haifu that this rubber suits a BH and not a FH if you loop really hard.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Spin: I see and feel very little difference in the spin generated from Shark 3 compared to my Tenergy.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Tenergy still has more but the effect on your oponent during the game is very similer.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: On serves it can do all the serves I can do with Tenergy but with far more control.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Short backspin serves can be done where the ball rolls back to the net after 3 or 4 bounces so plenty of spin.On my BH I can loop backspin more easily than I could with the Tenergy as the ball sinks into the sponge more and gives me more feeling.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Even though this rubber does have a lower throw than Tenergy it is not a big difference so I did not have to make too many changes to my technique.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Control :Here again this rubber so surprised me on my punch blocks.The ball just catapults off with a loud crack and goes wherever I wanted it to go.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I am not fighting with this rubber for control like other speed rubbers but feel it is working with me to put the ball in the right place.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The same goes for loops.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I would say it has 70% of the control I get from Tenergy which is really good as I find Tenergy to be one of the best control rubbers out there.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: On pushes this rubber is more springy but still retains it's control.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I will need to practice more to get my short pushes as short as I could with Tenergy but I think with a few more weeks of practice I will.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Other playing properties and comments :Put simply this rubber is a BEAST, period.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: If this rubber was put on a hard and fast 5-ply carbon blade then it would be a very formidable combination with huge possibilities of getting quite close to reliving the feeling of playing with a speed glued rubber.Besides the positives I have mentioned above there are a few negatives as well.The first negative is the price.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: For me it cost $15AUD less than my Tenergy!

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Granted it is not as expensive as the crazy priced $90+USD Whale 3 but asking close to a Tenergy price for a Chinese rubber is a pretty tough ask.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: My last Blue Whale 2 tuned lasted me about 2 days of training before a huge bubble appeared in the center.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Now I don't mind paying the premium price asked for Tenergy or any other Japanese rubber I have used as every single sheet I have ever bought has been flawless, never split or bubbled and lasted me far longer than the cheaper priced but soo short grip life of the bouncy ESN rubbers.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: So I gave the Chinese a second chance, thinking if they are charging close to a Japanese price for their top of the line rubber then they must be very proud and stand by their quality product.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Alas this brings me to my second negative, the durability.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: My flawless new sheet lasted 15 minutes before a bubble appeared.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Then after almost 30 minutes of hitting, small splits started to appear around the bubble.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The top sheet is as fragile as glass.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Even when cutting the rubber around my blade pieces just chipped off.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: When I stretched the off cut piece just a little, the top sheet splits instantly.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I could even peel the top sheet off easily from the sponge with little effort which is never a good sign, but with the Tenergy I can stretch an off cut and the sponge will tear long before the top sheet.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: This means either Haifu have tuned this rubber to an inch of its life and my loops are to much for the glue bonds to hold or they still have very poor quality control and are just trying to rip off Western buyers by charging massivly above the genuine and accurate price they charge within their own country.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It becomes a gamble if you get a good one or a bubbler like mine.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: Your current setup is fast blade + slow but firm rubber.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: This isn't a good combination for looping.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: The rubbers lack power and the blade + firm sponges require perfect timing, causing the crashes into the net.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: Firm sponges need to go with slower, softer blades.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: Avoid Tenergy and Tensors.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: Setup 1: Avalox BT550 (or similar soft, flexible allround blade, like Dawei Genote A+) + Gambler Wraith or IQUL 42 Deg.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: Max sponge.Setup 2: Your current blade + IQUL 40 deg.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: You will need to develop your technique to produce your own power.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: You will find IQUL / Wraith more powerful than Geospin.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: The extra dwell of the softer sponge or slow blade should stop the crashing into the net most of the time and give you enough dwell time to put in your own power.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: Either of those setups should get you over 2000 USATT.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: I could beat the majority of A Reserve players with either of those setups.I suggest investing money into coaching, at least once a week for a month.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: That will make the biggest difference.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: I would reccomend that you keep the blade you have and move up to a faster rubber.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: The best kind of speed is the speed we generate ourselves because that gives us more control over the game.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: IQUL in 40 degrees is a good looping rubber and not crazy fast.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: The 42 degree version is decidedly faster but it may not pair as well with your stiffer blade.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: The harder version is however better for the short game, pushing, blocking and is better at handling incoming serves.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: I think you will not be disappointed.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: I say to just save your money and too stick with chinese rubbers.The friendship 729 lightening, higher or the 729-05 are some great rubbers, in order slow to fast with a more jap feel than a traditional one but still with tack like you mentioned.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: The outlaw and hurricane neo are much faster maybe 20% more but have less grip or hardly any.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: I think i might throw in another side of the story  In order to switch from defensive to offensive gamestyle you need to go too a slower (5 layers without carbon) in order to inprove your skills.The problem with carbon blades is the they are very stiff and hard and therefore they offer very short dwell tim eand thereby control - when you have to change style it is too difficult to learn the strokes if the blade is too slow.

thread_title: Please suggest rubbers for me (chinese/Euro-Jap)
reply_split: In my opinion it is allways better to have fast rubbers and slower blade than fast blades and slow rubbers.I would think that a all+/off- blade would be a good choice.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: ask yourself: is it playing any different?

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Does it grip the ball as it did on the first weeks/months?You can also ask a regular playing partner who knows quite well of how you play.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Ask him if it was any different compare to before.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: That's what we do when trying to decide to get new rubbers/equipment or not.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: The physical appearance of the rubber can also be a good indicator of how used up it is.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: You can often see a significant difference on the rubber surface, if you compare the area where you usually hit the ball to the edges of the rubber or the part nearer the handle which stays relatively new.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: If there is a huge difference there it might be time to change the rubber.But more often then not, the best judge is playability.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Are your serves less spinny, loops have less kick in them, then I guess the rubber is dying, but not dead.At the end of the day it is a personal decision, some players change rubbers when they start to change characteristics, since they want to play with the rubber at its peak performance.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: And some extract every last bit of juice from their rubbers, something I would not encourage.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: As soon as another rubber takes your fancy.....oops, sorry, that's the EJ answer!!

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Seriously though, pay attention to how your rubber feels throughout its life in terms of its grippiness (on your serve, loop, chop, etc), its liveliness, how sweet your shots feel, stuff like that.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: When you feel dissatisfied with the rubber's performance, its time to change.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Some people find they don't mind playing with a dead-ish rubber and are happy to continue on with it.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Others find that they are surprised how good a new rubber feels against what their previous rubber had slowly degraded to.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: I don't think you can put any hard and fast rules on it though.

thread_title: what new rubbers plays like glued sriver/vario
reply_split: pretty much nothing plays close to a glued up rubber.

thread_title: Another new guy, rubber/blade question
reply_split: Welcome to the forum ScfishrWell, IMO the best thing you can do is to get a blade and rubbers that everybody knows and that allow you to compare with all other kind of rubber/blades (I call this a "Standard"), that allow to "build" your own game, style, and finally blade.OK, One typical Standard would be for example:Blade: Stiga OFFENSIVE or ALLROUNDRubbers: Yasaka Mark V 2.0 mm Red/black or Butterfly SriverIf you say that this combo is too fast, everybody in the world will understand what you mean, even if they have not watched you playing.Another (cheaper, chinese, slower) combo:Blade: LKT InstinctRubber: Friendship 729 (This combo is really easy and cheap to get in e-bay, for example)I'm sure that anyone can suggest you something to begin with.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: I feel that the Proton I am using now is about same speed to the Roxon, however with a much firmer sponge I feel the Proton is a little harder to control.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: Both still require a good stroke, but I feel the Roxon was just that touch more forgiving.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: So its control is not always just about the speed, the rubber characteristics can influence the control available at the same speed.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: Of course, there are other subtle differences too in the way different rubbers can play with respect to this.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: It's all about the short game for me, and as Yuzuki pointed out best tested in tense conditions.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: Am I comfortable touching short, can I dig a little extra on an occasional push, can I push an odd ball right off the bounce to get more spin, can I misdirect a push when I see an opponent move, can I receive serve well?

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: Can I do these things without constantly worrying about going too long.If I can do these things I will certainly be OK in the offensive and blocking games (and strangely also chopping away from the table).If I cannot the better players will destroy me with a superior short game- the foundation of a good player's skills.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: For me it's all about the short game.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: If I have trouble pushing or blocking then it is too fast.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: Service spin and how tight I can get the serve.

thread_title: Switching from Chinese FH Rubber to Euro/Jap
reply_split: On the other hand whenever you get an oppertunity try some of your mates blades and rubbers as this a quick way of trailing products and you will gain info on your mates likes and dislikes of thier gear Also keep an eye out for any German /Jap rubbers 1.8mm and over on special as there is nothing wrong with trying new stuff either:P

thread_title: Switching from Chinese FH Rubber to Euro/Jap
reply_split: Hi just remember to break your forehand shots down Firstly if thier ball is high (even with spin) adjust for the spin and then just hit the ball hard (try not to loop high balls ) Secondly Keep trying the 729 Cream Transcend but give it a clean as it may have lost its tack which helps you loop the longer ballsThirdly Sometimes when your opposition get your loops back it may be because you hit the the same place ,so vary your placement and this will help with your stroke play and statagy as well

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: A good topic, it's something I've wondered about too.A soft sponged rubber, expecially a thin one, is going to bottom out if your opponent hits it hard enough.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: The higher level you go, the harder they hit the ball.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: Brushing it really hard can reduce this effect, but I think this get really hard against fast balls.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: I suspect at the higher levels, they MUST be able to generate heavy backspin on their chops, and if a rubber bottoms out this will be harder to do.If you want to counter loop, then a really soft and thin sponge is hopeless as well, as it bottoms out even on medium pace loops.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: A 1.2mm sponge is very thin... we do have a few player that play with 1.8mm soft sponge, and are still able to loop quite effectively unless it's hit really hard...I think with a non-tacly rubber, it would be much easier to generate heavy backspin in the short game.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: For a hard sponged rubbers you'd need a tacky surface to do this so that you can brush it finely, where the hard sponge does not reduce the dwell time as well...These are the main contribting factors I can think off... Hopefully some of our inverted choppers can add some more comments?

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: It could probably well be the idea of being able to chop a hard-hit ball with good backspin.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
