thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: With harder sponge is easier to control where you want to put the ball, and it allows you to have more time for the ball to stick on tacky rubber so you can change the spin easily.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: I still remember my coach back then keep saying, chopping is not about putting the heaviest backspin on the ball, where you place it is the most important ones (Placement, speed, and control).

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: No matter how much backspin it has, if you place it not deep enough, or doesn't have enough speed, your opponent still can smash the ball.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: From my experience, it is easier to chop with hard sponge coz its more consistent, and you dont have to deal with bouncy sponge, so less variable to deal with.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: With hard sponge, you can chop the ball with shorter stokes (like ding song) which will give you plenty of time to react, plus it is easier to change the spin by varying short and long strokes.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: And, a BIG plus is you dont have to chop far far away from the table, so less running around.

thread_title: Platin 1,8 / max for the backhand.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: The issue with a rubber for chopping is that it doesn't want to be too fast or bouncy otherwise the ball is gone before you get much chance to inflict any great degree of spin on it.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: This means that a thicker sponge will eject the ball out quicker and be worse for chopping.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: Obviously the more grip you get from the topsheet the better, whereas with a looping rubber it can come from the sponge or the topsheet because you can apply more force to the ball as you are giving the ball downward force.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: It is more delicate chopping because you give upward force generally, so you can't rely much on the sponge to provide this, it has to come from the topsheet.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: A chopped ball will float in the air and go further, whereas a topspin ball will be dragged down by the spin force.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: So in seeking a chopping rubber you need to look for a very grippy or tacky topsheet with a thinner or deader sponge.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: Alternatively you can join us on the darkside and use long pimples which vary in the amount of chop spin they create themselves, but take the topspin of the opponent and send it back as underspin when using a chopping action.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: Anti-spin rubbers will do something similar, though I don't use it, so can't be very detailed on its effects.

thread_title: Is Andro Roxon 450 for me??//first impressions
reply_split: I've tried a number of other rubbers, but the Roxon is always one I come back to.I've had a lot of comments this season from players saying to me "wow, I found that very difficult to play against" and I say "yeah, well that's the pips for you" and they say "no, not the red side, that black side was causing me more problems, you just get so much spin from it".I've also had a lot of very good players in my division struggle to get my spin serves and loops when I connect well, just because R450 gives me so much more spin than anything else that I've used.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Deb, I haven't used Tenergy but I'd say the principals are the same.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I think generally a thinner sponge would be better for a flick for the extra control you get and the less catapulting that occurs to send the ball off beyond where you intended.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: However, I would say the more important thing is having the correct technique and blade angle for the shot and for the rubber and sponge you are using.So overall, I think sponge thickness is not as important as getting the shot right.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I would recommend 1.9 in some other rubber.The Tenergy is Very Hard and does not work well with very hard stiff blades.I myself use Platin on my Bh because the Tenergy is to hard and 2 sheets of Tenergy will be too heavy.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Yes I think the sponge does not matter so much for the flick, as it's a low impact shot...so I'd choose 1.9mm for better control.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: thanks for the feedback ... i used to think spinny topsheet rubbers are good for flick... but i read some post where silver mention less spinny rubbers are better for flick.. confusing.anyway i ordered xiom zeta only reason being its $30 and available in US.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: till it arrives... i will let my ee2 work on the 729 reactor sponge.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Maybe he said that in the sense that not too spinny sheets will help on controlling the service spin, especially if you flick without a lot of spin.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Good point Yuz, cos there is the flat flick and there is the toppy type flick you need to go over it.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I find flicks from close to the net one of the harder shots cos I don't have the reach to really control the stroke well.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Anybody have this problem?

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Well, if I think about it, my belly tends to hit the table first before I get to reach close to the net, yep.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: The backhand flick/loop is my longtime favorite shot and my main offensive weapon.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Because this shot has no backswing or other telltale, when I execute it properly -- particularly on a short ball or unsuspecting serve -- it's usually behind my opponent before they have a chance to even begin moving their paddle.I recently bought Tihbar Nimbus Soft for a med fast 9-ply homemade blade that I use.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Paddle Palace convinced me that I didn't want max sponge for my BH so I got the second thickest for BH (in black) and max on the FH (in red).It turns out that there was a noticeable difference in how those two sheets played, particularly on my BH flick/loop.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: The thinner sponge bottomed out easily and often went long.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: The max sponge never bottomed out and would take far shorter paths to the table.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I was surprised that so little difference in sponge thickness could make such a difference.If you brush loop your flick shots as I sometimes do then sponge thickness isn't nearly as critical (then it's all about keeping your topsheet clean).

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: But if you drive into the ball I think you'll want all the thick, soft sponge you can get.UPDATE: I've since had the chance to hit some more with Tenergy 2.1 and find its dense, springy sponge (which is nothing like Nimbus) virtually impossible to fully compress.. but also (on the right blade) very compelling!

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I'm ordering my own sheet soon.. in 1.9 for my bh.

thread_title: BEST TENSOR / GLUE EFFECT RUBBER FOR SPINNY PUSHES AND CHOPS
reply_split: I think your looking for a chinese rubber.Most tensors are too soft for making good underspin.I would Recommend Globe 999 or Geospin tacky.

thread_title: BEST TENSOR / GLUE EFFECT RUBBER FOR SPINNY PUSHES AND CHOPS
reply_split: from RITC.The problem with tensors is that they are way to springy and therefore you cannot generate enough underspin.You see the same problem when returning serves with tensors the ball jumps instead of sways away from the rubber.I myself have switched from soft tensor rubbers to hars tensor rubbers.I have switched from silver to Tenergy in FH and Platin in BH.Tenergy is on the other hand very spinny both extremely hard and fast and therefore it might be impossible to control as a chopper.They do only sell Tenergy to very good players since it is hard to control this hard rubber in the bh.Platin is also medium hard and also very fast it will be way to fast to control in the bh for chopping - that`s why you could not get any soin from it the contact time is very short for this rubber.Both these rubbers are attackers rubbers not choppers.What do you play at the moment ?

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: I agree that spin can't be completely judged by the arc of the ball, however the part about the bullet doesn't translate to table tennis.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: Bullets have screwball spin so they basically travel straight independent of spin and speed.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: Looped table tennis balls travel with topspin, and the flight of the ball varies depending on both the spin and the speed.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: The faster the ball, the more downward force is applied by the air above the spinning ball.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: If i recall correctly it's a velocity-squared relation so a 60mph loop experiences four times as much downforce as a 30mph loop.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: The faster loop will hit the ground before the slower loop.Though ideally you'd want the loop to hit the table, not the ground, and determining whether it's advantageous to hit harder to get more arc is much too complicated to figure in any given situation.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: Instincts and your practice partner's observations work a lot better.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: I was hitting with someone who was using some tensor stuff, and they were really consistent looping with it in practice (personally i think the control on the stuff is awful).

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: Unfortunately their loops had nice arc and hit the table not because of great spin or control, but rather because the loops were all really really slow.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: I agree there is more downforce on a faster ball but you are leaving out the increased momentum of the ball.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: If what you say is correct, a ball looped hard would have a sharper arc than a slow ball.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: I think there are to many factors for us to solve it here.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: I know if you put a rubber on a slow blade and loop one, it has a sharper arc than if you put it on a fast blade.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: I doubt if the amount of spin is much different while the arc is very different.The bullet anolagy was the only one I could think of to try and give an idea about how spin/speed relate.The blade angle required to block a loop tells alot about how much spin is on a ball.Like it was mentioned, another person receiving the ball will have a good idea how much spin was really on the ball.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: Yes a faster ball has higher momentum, but the momentum is horizontal so it's irrelevant when looking at how quickly the ball will drop.Given two balls with equal rpms and different speeds, the faster ball definitely has a sharper arc, as the force of air resulting from spin is more than gravity.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: (Whether the sharper arc is enough to overcome the fact that it spends less time over the table is unknown.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: )Yeah, the person receiving the ball ought to have a good idea of how much spin is really on the ball.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: However that person also needs to understand how their racket reacts to spin.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: A more closed racket does not mean the ball has more spin and speed; a lot of times a faster ball with equal spin requires a more open racket.

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum
reply_split: Yes intuitively I'd say you're right, but it's hard to prove since we have no way of imparting equal spin at different speeds.I also think faster loops often carry less spin, as you tend to put more energy into speed instead of spinning the ball... a lot of exceptions to this of course...

thread_title: Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O. Platinum

thread_title: Review Galaxy/Yinhe Venus 36-38deg 2.0mm black (boosted)
reply_split: Hi Hookshot...I have LKT Pro XT which is a tacky rubber as the name says..(XT = extra tacky) and that has remained tackier than it was new for 3 - 4 months now with Spinmax, and an occasional treatment of Eucalyptus Oil and a stint in the sun or under a light for 2 hours brings up that glossy tack that I cannot live without...lol....Its quite dramatic what the EO does and the rubbers just slurp it up...apart from helping maintain tackiness, this EO treatment causes the topsheet to become tuned...Ie the increased size makes the topsheet more dense and adds speed..Anyway, it might not be a bad idea to get some Spinmax Aqueous from Alex...it would be there before you know it, and also try the EO in the sunlight if your sun is warm, or 100 watt light globe at about 12 inches ...watch the heat.I gave a sheet of Mercury (Venus's sister rubber with a Chinese sponge) to a friend a few weeks ago, and he has maintained the rubber tackier than it was at new using the above treatment regime...I do realise I sound a bit like a broken record going on about Spinmax and EO,  but the fact is that they work!!
